title: brexit new immigration rules explained eu citizens work points system
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Threshold of 70 points need to apply for visa under new rulesThe government has revealed a new points-based immigration plan which will come into force on 1 January next year.Under the post-Brexit rules, free movement will be replaced by a minimum salary threshold of £25,600 for most workers – lower than the £30,000 proposed under Theresa May’s premiership.It is hoped the “firm but fair” system will attract “high-skilled workers” to create a “high wage, high skill, high productivity” economy.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe Tories have vowed to prioritise people based on their skills rather than where they come from, adding: “For too long, distorted by European free movement rights, the immigration system has been failing to meet the needs of the British people.”Migrants will be charged about&nbsp£1,200 for a work visa, or £900 in a shortage occupation – the same fee as paid by non-EU migrants currently.So what exactly is in the government’s controversial new immigration plan?How many points do I need?All applicants – both EU and non-EU citizens – who want to live and work in the UK will need to gain 70 points to be eligible to apply for a visa.Points will be awarded for key requirements and they must meet three criteria, which total 50 points.&nbspHave a job offer from an approved sponsor, such as an employer cleared by the Home Office (20 points).Have a job offer that is at a “required skill level” (20 points).They can speak English to B1 level, enabling someone to, for example, open a bank account, or cope with “most situations” at home, work or leisure. (10 points).How do I earn extra points?Those who meet the first three conditions can then earn extra points to reach the threshold of 70 points by having:Salary of £25,600 or above (20 points).Job in an occupation where there are staff shortages, designated by the Migration Advisory Committee, such as the NHS, vets, architects (20 points).PhD in subject relevant to the job (10 points).PhD in a STEM (science, technology, engineering, maths) subject relevant to the job (20 points).The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailWhat about low-skilled workers?There will be no temporary or general visa options for low-skilled migrant workers, other than seasonal workers.The government has argued there are already huge numbers of EU citizens and 170,000 recently-arrived non-EU citizens for such jobs.However, a pilot scheme for seasonal workers in agriculture will be quadrupled from 2,500 to 10,000 places.What qualifications do I need?The government has lowered the skill level required to count as “skilled” from graduate level to A-level.What about students?Students must be able “to support themselves” but will be able to stay on in the UK and work for two years after graduation.They will need to demonstrate:&nbspThey have an offer from an approved educational institution.&nbspCan support themselves during their studies in the UK.&nbspCurrent arrangements for specialist occupations such as religious ministers, artists, musicians and entertainers are expected to broadly remain the same and be extended for EU citizens.What if I’m self-employed?Self-employed and freelance workers can continue to apply for visas under existing rules and will not need to be sponsored.Do I need a visa to visit?Visitors, including EU citizens, will be able to come to the UK without a visa for six months but will not be allowed to work.What about asylum seekers?Asylum applications fall outside the points-based system and are expected to operate under existing rules.What if I'm not sponsored?There will also be an “unsponsored” visa option where points will also be awarded for factors such as academic qualifications, age and relevant work experience for a small number of highly-skilled workers without a job offer. The route would be capped to begin with.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - Part of an extensive set of sculptures that adorned the Parthenon temple and other buildings on the Acropolis in Athens, the 500BC marbles were brought to the UK by Lord Elgin in the early-19th-century.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe peer said at the time that he had received permission from the Ottoman Empire, which then occupied&nbspGreece, to transport the story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Minister insisted that changes were 'not about my background or my parents'Home secretary Priti Patel has conceded in an interview on LBC radio that her parents may not have been admitted to the UK under the immigration rules she is proposing.Interviewer Nick Ferrari - who traces his own background to an immigrant in the catering industry - told the home secretary that under her own rules: You wouldn't be here.She replied: Yeah, but also let's not forget we are not changing our approach to refugees and asylum seekers, which is very different to a points-based system for employment and that particular route.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesMs Patel later suggested that her family&nbspmay have been dealt with under arrangements for those fleeing mistreatment abroad, rather than those for migrant workers, as they had faced persecution in Uganda.Her&nbspparents came to the UK from the east African state in the 1960s and set up a chain of newsagents. However, their arrival came before&nbspdictator Idi Amin's mass expulsion of Uganda Asians &nbspin 1972, which saw many families forced to flee the country and admitted to the UK under their status as colonial citizens.The home secretary initially attempted to dodge the question of whether her own family would have been affected by the new immigration rules.Created with Sketch.UK news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Models on the catwalk during the Bobby Abley show at London Fashion WeekRachel Cox inspecting flood damage in her kitchen in Nantgarw, south Wales, where residents are returning to their homes to survey and repair the damage in the aftermath of Storm DennisTeme Street in Tenbury Wells is seen under floodwater from the overflowing River Teme, after Storm Dennis caused flooding across large swathes of BritainModels present creations at the Richard Quinn catwalk show during London Fashion Week in LondonResigned as Chancellor of the Exchequer. purporting to represent the owner.Irish government officials were contacted by the unnamed inidual after the MV Alta was blown onto rocks near a fishing village in County Cork&nbspon Sunday.The 77-metre-long cargo vessel had been drifiting&nbspacross the Atlantic for more than a year after it lost power 1,300 miles southeast of Bermuda.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesCork County Council has warned the public to stay away from the “unstable” wreck because of its location on a “dangerous and inaccessible stretch of coastline”.However photographers have flocked to the title: rose dont be a thorn in natalies side
story: After all, her incredibly brave allegations of rape and sexual assault levelled at the then all-powerful Miramax boss Harvey Weinstein blazed the trail for the #MeToo movement that emerged in .And she has been a fearless activist ever since, pursuing justice and equality.But I’m afraid it was a dud move on her part to criticise actress Natalie Portman for her decision to walk the red carpet at Sunday night’s Oscars wearing a custom Dior gown and cape, which was adorned with the names of some of the female directors who weren’t nominated this year.In her own way, Natalie wanted to shine a lighton the fact that, for the ninth year in the past decade, all five of the best director nominees were male.The female directors highlighted on Natalie’s gown included Lorene Scafaria , Lulu Wang , Greta Gerwig , Marielle Hellerand Melina Matsoukas .Whatever you think about her way of doing it, there’s no doubt she made a point.And the fact that she was standing on the red carpet made it a more powerful point thanshe had, say, boycotted the event or stood outside with a placard.But in a social media post, Rose McGowan referred to ­Portman’s cape as: “The kind of protest that gets rave reviews from the mainstream media for its ­bravery.”“Brave ”, she wrote. “No, not by a long shot. More like an actress acting the part of someone who cares. As so many of them do.“I find Portman’s type of activism deeply offensive to those of us who actually do the work. I’m not writing this out of bitterness, I am writing out of disgust,” she wrote.Unfortunately, coming from someone who has been so integral in the protest movement, this sounds like sour grapes.Natalie’s response to Rose’s criticism was as elegant and as understated as her protest.She said: “I agree with Ms McGowan that it is inaccurate to call me ‘brave’ for wearing a garment with women’s names on it.“Brave is a term I more strongly associate with actions like those of the women who have been testying against Harvey Weinstein the last few weeks.”She also responded to Rose’s accusation that Natalie has only been directed twice by women.But in this criticism, Rose is seriously missing the point. Female directors don’t get as far in Hollywood as male ones, which is precisely what Natalie is pointing out with her cloak protest. Therefore, there are fewer available to work with.As Natalie said: “It is true I’ve only made a few films with women. In my long career, I’ve only gotten the chance to work with female directors a few times . . . Unfortunately, the unmade films I have tried to make are a ghost history.“Female films have been incredibly hard to get made at studios, or to get independently financed. If these films do get made, women face enormous challenges during the making of them.”By the way, this is not the first time Natalie has protested from within the system.While presenting the best director category at the Golden Globes in , she introduced the line-up by saying: “And here are the all-male nominees.”Again, it’s not a shouty, noisy street protest. But it served to make her point. Just that she did it in a dferent way than Rose might. And that’s fine.In fact, some people think that Rose’s in-your-face type of protest risks alienating some people.I think women should support each other when it comes to vying for equality.But also, Rose just sounded spiteful when she said Natalie was “an actress acting like someone who cares”.Rose is a hero to many women. But she needs to understand that whether their contribution is big or small, loud or subtle, anyone’s effort to affect change helps.JANE Fonda, who looked fabulous at the Oscars, has said she is done with plastic surgery.Well, I guess  is as good an age as any to stop nipping and tucking.She must have a great doctor, as whatever the actress has had done has been done very well indeed – because, in my experience, it’s not often you look better after a facelt than you did before.PERHAPS Andrea Leadsom had a premonition that she was going to be axed as Business Secretary in this week’s Cabinet reshuffle.She recently wrote a column obliquely warning Boris Johnson not to cut the number of female ministers in his Cabinet.Addressing the issue of female board members among FTSE  companies, Andrea wrote: “Working in the City in the Nineties, I saw myself how a male-dominated environment can limit a career.”Unfortunately for her, the warning did not save her skin and she has been sacked, along with Theresa Villiers as Environment Secretary and housing minister Esther McVey.By the way, eight of the  members of Mr Johnson’s first Cabinet were female –  per cent.Despite these sackings, that figure has actually risen – slightly – to nearly  per cent.Ideally, the split would be an even -.But the reality is that business and politics can both be brutal.Men and women alike must accept they might one day get the sack.It simply goes with the territory.Being selected on the basis of gender is just as wrong as being sacked on that basis.Right person, right job, regardless of their gender.THAT is what true equality means.SAY what you like about the bonkers lestyle advice dispensed by Gwyneth Paltrow on Goop – and some of it is seriously out there.But whatever she is doing clearly works.She is, at the age of , nothing short of radiant.In fact she looks amazing and also happy.Not only that but she became instantly relatable to parents everywhere with a confession that her -year- old daughter finds her embarrassing.That’s a good reminder there is nothing like a teenager to keep you normal and down to earth for fear that you will embarrass them, no matter what you do.Although, to be fair, perhaps Gwyneth’s daughter has had a predisposition to feel embarrassed by her mother ever since she named her  . . . Apple.What are the ethics of seat-reclining on a long-haul flight An American Airlines passenger raised the question after video-shaming a fellow traveller who punched and pushed her seat when she reclined it.Bearing in mind the recline button moves the seat about in, I suspect this chap has anger issues, as reclining a seat that has a recline button is hardly an act of aggression.I’d disable the recline button and then all you have to fight over is the armrest.DAMIAN Hurleys resemblance to his mother, Liz, is uncanny.More so than ever in the latest shots of the two of them together, which he posted online this week.Some people think it is vaguely unsettling that he looks more like Liz Hurley than Liz Hurley.But as a mum myself, I think it’s heartwarming a teenage boy should be so happy to emulate his mother.OH the utter folly of the face tattoo!The latest to succumb to this trend, which a few years ago would be, frankly, unthinkable, is Amber Rose.She has had the words Bash and Slash tattooed across her forehead in old English manuscript style.It’s a reference, apparently, to the model’s three-month-old son Slash, and six-year-old son Sebastian. And, obviously, it’s lovely that she loves her children so much.But tattooing their names on her forehead where they will remain for all her le  All I can say is: Tattoo in haste . . . repent at leisure.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: caroline flack honesty sunshine our life inspired
story: She was also one of the most honest.Unlike so many of our cosseted household names she was approachable, witty and refreshingly open about her own le and struggles.She spoke with candour about her career and her personal le.She was unafraid to open up about her fears and in that way she inspired fans to be open and honest about the problems we all face in le at dferent times.She was a brilliant host of Love Island — funny and insightful without ever being patronising towards the contestants.Her untimely death is a tragedy, the third associated with the show and its future must now be in doubt.The Crown Prosecution Service needs to take a long look in the mirror and ask why it pursued its course of action given what they knew about her vulnerability.We may never know exactly what drove Caroline over the edge.But we will always remember how, like the weather at the TV villa, she brought so much sunshine into our lives.The Duchess of Cambridge’s candour about the joys and pressures of motherhood is to be applauded.Kate’s moving honesty in a new podcast about her feelings of loneliness and “mum guilt” will chime with women across the country.And the fact our future Queen has expressed her feelings so publicly shows how she is subtly modernising the monarchy as well as gaining in self- confidence.The contrast with Meghan and Harry’s complaints about being in the media spotlight will not be lost on the public.While the Sussexes have quit their Royal duties, Kate has kept working hard for her husband and the “firm”.She had to put up with years of jibes about her family and fashion sense, but the nation has now taken her to its heart.We are lucky – and proud – to have this Duchess of Dignity.BRITAIN’S standards in areas like the environment, the minimum wage and workers’ rights are higher than many EU countries.But Brussels is bizarrely demanding that we LOWER our internationally admired regulationswe want to sign up to its tarf-free trade deal.Boris must stick to his mantra of levelling up, not levelling down, and resist the Eurocrats’ race to the bottom.Anything  would betray voters.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make title: brexit points based immigration system
story: This Government promised to get Brexit done and we delivered.But that wasn’t our only promise you overwhelmingly backed at the ballot box.We also promised to deliver a points-based immigration system that delivers for the whole of the United Kingdom and this week we will set out plans do just that.On Friday, the new Cabinet backed mine and the Prime Minister’s vision to take back control of who comes to this country.We agreed a radical, new, firm but fair system that rewards the skills people have to offer, not where they come from.Sun on Sunday readers have been with us on this journey.And I can make another promise, that you will finally have an immigration system that works in the interests of our country.For too long firms have relied on cheap, foreign low-skilled labour rather than investing in our workers.They have exploited free movement to undercut you, taking away jobs and driving down wages.For too long we were powerless to help, shackled by Europe and forced to be rule-takers. Ending free movement changes all that.The Government has listened to the clear message from the  referendum and the  General Election that the public wants a reduction in low-skilled immigration.We want to see overall numbers down and this new system will deliver. Our new immigration system will turn off the tap of cheap, foreign low-skilled labour.Workers coming to the UK will have to prove they have something to offer.We are not closing our doors, but we will finally be able to choose who comes through them.We will attract the top talent from anywhere in the world.Allowing us to attract the brightest and the best from around the globe who will help our economy to thrive.From next year, all skilled workers will need to earn enough points to work in the UK.They will need to speak English, have a firm job offer, and meet the salary requirements.Extra points will be awarded to people who have the most to offer, including those working in a profession where there is a real skills shortage.We will continue to monitor – through expert advisers –there are shortages and gaps to be filled.For those coming to work in our NHS and schools, points will be awarded in line with pay scales for their professions.This is only the beginning, and this week we will set out our plans to go even further with a system to deliver the reforms you want.For the first time in decades, the UK will have control over who comes to our great country and how our immigration system works.We’ve got Brexit done, now we’re moving on to focus on the people’s other priorities.We promised to unleash our country’s full potential and we are doing just that. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc licence fee leo mckinstry abolish
story: The creaking corporation is almost a century old, and nowhere is that more apparent than in its defence of the hopelessly outdated licence fee.The Beeb likes to pose as a beacon of fairness, yet it is subsidised by a draconian compulsory charge that should have no place in a modern free society.On pain of criminal prosecutions, all owners of television sets are forced to bankroll BBC staff, regardless of whether they ever use its services or not.Lets be clear: it is fundamentally wrong that people should have to pay for something they do not want.That is why the Government is right to consider the abolition of the licence fee within the next few years, moving to a subscription-based service.Such a move, which could happen before the BBC’s charter is renewed in , would be entirely in step with our times.After all, nearly half of British households already subscribe to streaming channels like Netflix. And more people now watch YouTube than all terrestrial broadcasters put together.Even the BBCs highest paid star, Gary Lineker, says its time to make the fee voluntary, while Dame Helen Mirren admits its had its day.Yet the Government’s policy has provoked howls of outrage, especially from the chattering liberals who seem to regard the licence fee as a sacred part of our constitution.Their squeals of protest are badly misplaced. The fact is that, by guaranteeing a huge revenue stream, the licence fee promotes a culture of excess and mismanagement within the BBC, which has a budget of almost £ billion and employs , people.Its reflected in the vast salaries paid to scores of BBC stars, far beyond market rates, like the £. million previously dished out to Lineker, £, to newsreader Huw Edwards, or the £, to sports presenter Jason Mohammad.You can spot it in the host of botched or extravagant schemes, like the notorious reconstruction of the EastEnders set, whose budget soared from £ million to £. million.Worse still, a staggering £ billion was spent on the refurbishment of Broadcasting House in central London.There is also absurd doubling up among staff, particularly in the news.Last week, the BBC had  correspondents covering the American Democrat primaries in Iowa and New Hampshire, while in  no fewer than  on-air journalists were sent to report on one brief Brussels summit attended by David Cameron.But the lack of any commercial pressure is most easily spotted in the vast, sprawling tiers of flabby bureaucracy.Ab Fab comedian Jenner Saunders once said of the corporation, “It’s become top-heavy in such an ugly way,” adding that it is “an executive-run place for idiots”.A glance through the BBC’s Annual Report for  shows just how correct she was.On these pages, I counted no fewer than eight managers who had “Human Resources Director” in their job titles, all of them on at least £,-a-year.Among them were: Dale Haddon, “HR Director, News and Employee Relations”, on up to £, Rachel Currie, “BBC Group HR Director” on up to £, and Gillian Taylor, “HR Director” on £,.It was the same story with BBC News, whose regiment of well-healed officials included: Fran Unsworth, the “Director of News” on £, Gavin Allen, “Head of News Output” on £, and Jonathan Munroe, Head of Newsgathering” on £,.This grasping spirit prevails throughout the bloated organisation, from the £, “Director of Nations and Regions” to the £, “Director of Radio and Education.”Insulated by public funding, the corporation adores both navel-gazing and self-promotion. So it has a “Director of Communications” on £,-a-year, a “Director of Policy” on £, and a “Director of Editorial Policy” on £,.All that puts into perspective the current moans from the BBC about the need for cuts.But apart from the managerial excess, what also aggravates is how the corporation uses its publicly-funded muscle to promote a fashionable, London-centric agenda.As the state’s monopoly broadcaster, the BBC should be utterly impartial.Yet its output is dominated by trendy political messages on immigration, climate change, Tory cuts, ersity and poverty.The BBC might have lavished reporters on the Democrat primaries, but it gave hardly any live coverage to the recent celebrations in Parliament Square at the moment of Brexit.Typically a Newsnight discussion  that evening – held in a studio bedecked with the blue and gold of the EU - featured two Remainers and one Brexiteer.Left-wing propaganda is continually crowbarred into everything from drama to discussion programmes.Just  per cent of the national workforce is employed in the public sector, yet the BBC is filled with the voices of state employees, most of them whining about under-funding.Left-wing opinions have a stranglehold most topical comedy shows, such as Radio Four’s News Quiz, hosted by the achingly unfunny Nish Kumar.It was Kumar who recently caused a storm by sneeringly presenting an edition of the BBC children’s show “Horrible Histories”, in which Britain’s Victorian past was held up for ridicule.The BBC can get away with this because of its lucrative monopoly as the state’s only broadcaster. It has abused that privileged position for too long.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jars of preserved human tongues dating back 50 years are found hidden in house
story: The large white containers were discovered in a crawlspace, under the floorboards of the home, local news station WCJB reported Monday.They were found during an inspection of a house in Gainesville, Fla., and some of them date back to the s.Each jar is labeled with a name and date and reportedly holds about one gallon.At least six jars contained formaldehyde and body parts. Some contained human tongues.According to WCJB, a former University of Florida researcher at one time owned the house.The retired professor, Dr. Ronald A. Baughman, published studies in the s and s.Hours after the frightening Monday discovery, a man claiming to be the home inspector who notied police wrote to Reddit: Today I was inspecting a crawl space for foundation issues. Once I crawled in I saw quite a few old children’s toys.Lots of old construction debris as well. All well aged, covered in dust, spider webs and mold.Further in I discovered - plastic jars. I looked at them and noticed masking tape with a single name on each. First names. Human names like Angela, Heather, Virginia, etc.I was going to continue the inspection, but … those first names didn’t sit right with me.He added: I went back and found that one jar was rusted through on top. Inside I saw a plastic bag and immediately what looked like small bones.I removed the bag and almost immediately realized it was actually a small infant child. Her first name written on the exterior. The details of her little face were still very much preserved.The unidentied man later shared footage of the container to Reddit, which apparently contained human tongues.When the man described photographing the jugs and tongues, he said he thought they were dead mice.Gainesville Police are investigating the jars as they may be related to Baughmans work.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: the bbc is untrustworthy licence fee choice
story: THE culture war over the BBC licence fee is in full force.And predictably the usual campaign from the typical Beeb scare mongers has begun.So let me start by saying: No one is suggesting closing the BBC. No one is suggesting you won’t have Strictly Come Dancing or Match of the Day or even Question Time and Newsnight.But the media is fundamentally changing. Consumer choice – what you or me choose to consume on the box or on our iPads or phones and at what time – is king.The idea that by  paying £. for a service that we may choose not to watch or listen to AT ALL is insanity.It might be unpleasant for BBC lers but the time has come to accept that the licence fee must evolve into a subscription service, so that the corporation is accountable to viewers and not the current behemoth that puts local newspapers out of business, that competes with national newspaper websites to write about Love Island, and that makes podcasts like Reality Tea all about the MTV reality series Geordie Shore.That is NOT public service broadcasting. It is a blatant and constant attempt to undercut struggling commercial rivals.But a sea change is coming. I truly feel it.Sure, there might be disagreement at Downing Street about exactly what that change will involve.Personally I’m on the side of Dominic Cummings who wants wholescale cuts. Sell Radio  and Radio , shut down the sweeping BBC Online department and focus on true public service programming that won’t be provided where. Then in  allow people the choice about whether they want to pay for what they watch from the BBC or not.But the plan by Boris Johnson - who The Times reports this morning fancies an evolution not a revolution - is also valid. The first step to decriminalise the licence fee is the start of bringing the BBC back in line.The fact we’re even having this discussion is the fault of the BBC, which has proven itself to be untrustworthy and lacking in political impartiality in recent years.It disgraced itself over its coverage of Brexit. title: first woman pass parachute regiments selection
story: An insider said: “She blitzed it.”Capt Wild, , who was pictured with Camilla after receiving the Sword of Honour at Sandhurst in , joins  Parachute Regiment, Royal Artillery.Over five days she completed eight tough tests including a  second boxing bout against a male recruit – who sources say she “flattened.”One source said: “She even won her milling bout, there was no doubting her toughness, she’s a Para now and worthy of the maroon beret.“Not many thought a woman would ever pass P Company, she’s proved a lot of people wrong.”In order to pass P Company Captain Wild- dubbed Britains hardest female soldier - completed a  mile march over rough terrain carrying a bergen weighing lbs plus water and weapon in under one hour and  minutes.Next is the Trainasium – an aerial assault course  feet up – testing nerves.Candidates then have to work in a team of eight for the log race – carrying a kgs log over . miles of rough terrain.Captain Wild would then have to run the Steeplechase, a . mile cross country run though water obstacles, before then completing an assault course, in under  minutes.The following test includes a two mile march with a Bergen weighing lbs and a weapon in under  minutes.Candidates must also complete the Endurance march over  miles of severe terrain carrying a Bergen, and weapon, in under four and a half hours.And there is a Stretcher Race, with teams of  carrying a lbs stretcher over five miles. title: home secretary priti patel unveils points based immigration system
story: The Home Secretary on Tuesday night declared low skilled immigration will come to a dramatic end in just ten months time on January ,  when free movement from the EU halts.Priti Patel published for the first time the full details of the new post-Brexit points-based system that will replace cheap labour from Europe.Signalling the need for better pay and conditions, the Home Office insisted: “Employers will need to adjust.“It is important that employers move away from a reliance on the immigration system as an alternative to investment in staff retention, productivity, and wider investment in technology and automation”.Ministers are confident that their tough crackdown on low skilled immigration will see Boris Johnson’s election promise to reduce the overall number of incomers fulfilled.But The Sun has learned thatthat fails, they will reintroduce annual caps on the number of skilled workers coming in.A government source said: “We will cap overall numberswe really have to.”In the biggest change of all, there will be no route into the country for low skilled workers.Skilled workers will be able to comethey are able to tot up at least  points, accrued via the level of salary they are offered and their abilities.But a job offer and the ability to speak English will be mandatory for all of them.While most will be expected to earn a minimum of £, a year, some such as lab technicians with prized skills will be able to come in with a salary as low as £,.The definition of skilled workers is to be downgraded to mean anyone who has an A level-style qualication, instead of degree level now – meaning plasterers and bricklayers could qualy for working visas.But hospitality workers will be excluded.There will also be special exemptions for pinch trades where there are shortages, such as doctors and nurses.Highly skilled workers, such top academics and scientists, will be able to come in without a job offerthey are endorsed by a top institution.Ms Patel said: “It is right that people should speak English before they come to our country, that they should have a sponsored route, whether it’s through employment or a sponsored route through an academic institution”.Business bosses warned the crackdown could leave some firms struggling.BCC Director General Adam Marshall said: “The speed and scale of these changes will require signicant adjustment by businesses.“Companies are already investing heavily in home-grown talent across the UK, but critical labour shortages mean firms will still need access to overseas workers at all skill levels.”Immigration campaigners also sounded the alarm, and warned ministers the plan will not control numbers.We agree with swapping an open door to unlimited numbers of unskilled EU workers for a controlled flow of the brightest and best from across the globe — including the EU.And the Government is quite right to warn company bosses they must “do more” to employ UK-based workers.It’s simply not fair that Brits have been squeezed out of jobs by big companies taking advantage of cheap foreign labour, and the imbalance has rankled with voters for decades.But there’s a fly in the ointment.Will this plan do much to bring down the overall immigration numbers as the Tories have long promised Migration Watch UK Chairman Alp Mehmet said: “These proposals suggest that the government is not serious about taking control of immigration.“Not only will millions of UK workers see their jobs opened up to new or greater competition from overseas workers in much poorer countries but employers will no longer have to look to find anyone at home before searching abroad.“With no cap on numbers coming via the main route from the outset, this is a massive risk that will alarm the  million people who were expecting this government finally to deliver on their long-standing promises to reduce immigration and show belief in young Brits, rather than giving in to the demands of bosses.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. country of origin, with the new system focusing on youth, education and fluency in English or French.Australia and New Zealand also have points systems.All three have similarities to the system the UK uses for non-EU migrants, although each system awards dferent numbers of points for dferent attributes.In Australia, being aged between  and  years old will get you  points - almost halfway to the eligibility threshold of  points.Just now, people from within the EU do not need a visa to work in the UK as free movement is still in place  - however there are limits on claiming certain benefits.A points-based system is already in place for those from outside the EU, with points awarded for having English language skills, being sponsored by a company and meeting a salary threshold.A maximum number of work visas -  around , a year - are issued but it isnt often met.Based on points accrued, there are four tiers of visa.Other visas such as family ones for relatives of people coming on work title: coronavirus cruise gets worse cant leave ship evacuation
story: But the Foreign Office has warned UK passengers who disembark the virus ravaged ship, they may not be able to join the evacuation flight home.Brits have also been warned they face another two weeks of quarantine on their .Only those who test negative and show no symptoms of the coronavirus will be allowed on the flight, it is believed.In a statement, the Foreign Office said: We are planning an evacuation flight from Tokyo to the UK as soon as possible for Britons who are on the Diamond Princess.We hope the flight will be later this week, subject to permissions from the Japanese authorities.At am local time on Wednesday, the Diamond Princess cruise operator and Japanese authorities allowed passengers to disembark from the cruise ship.However there is a chance that people who disembark will not be able to join the evacuation flight.We have the utmost concern for the affected Britons and strongly encourage them to register for the evacuation flight.Around  US passengers have already been evacuated, with Australia, Canada and Hong Kong chartering planes for their nationals today according to Princess Cruises.Speaking to BBC Radio s Today this morning, trapped Brit Elaine Spencer said she was disappointed with the UKs slow response to the disastrous situation.Elaine, who doesnt know when she will be allowed home and has only been vaguely told a flight will be arranged by the end of the week said: [Were] still in limbo.Im disappointed, its like everyone going to a party and youre left behind.Elaine says she believes the UK Government have failed to organise appropriate evacuation flights, which is frustrating.The Foreign Office, while hopeful to get the stranded passengers home as soon as possible, are yet to arrange the chartered flight from Yokohama, Japan where the ship is docked.It comes as the plague ship was overcome with the highest rate of infection outside mainland China.They this morning confirmed  new cases of the killer flu, totalling  infections on board overall.Authorities ordered , passengers and crew to remain on board the Diamond Princess - but instead of stopping the spread it created a boiling pot of transmission leading to  cases on board so far.Not all passengers will be freed from the Diamond Princess liner on Wednesday, which has been docked in Yokohama since February .A number of scientists say the ship served as an incubator instead of a quarantine facility meant to prevent the worsening of an outbreak.In fact, three Japanese health officials who helped in the quarantine checks on the ship were also infected.Despite this, authorities in the country have defended quarantine processes.Around , crew members were told to wear surgical masks, wash their hands, use disinfectant sprays and stop operations at restaurants, bars and other entertainment areas after February .The ships quarantine has been blasted by experts, with Nathalie MacDermott, an outbreak expert at King’s College London saying plainly that it obviously...hasnt worked.As the UK government scrambles to organise an evacuation flight for trapped passengers, things are still unclear for abandoned Brits David and Sally Abel.The pair say they were mistaken in believing they had tested positive for coronavirus.In Davids latest Facebook post, he said: “Sally  I packed and waited  hours in the cabin to be transported to a hostel.“We are still on the ship! title: prince andrew birthday instagram post

title: china open and ready to deliver post brexit trade deal top diplomat says
story: The Chinese ambassador to London Liu Xiaoming said the country is ready to restart the bumper trade deal talks that were paused during last years Brexit deadlock.Speaking to Sky News, the diplomat warned it may take time because of the coronavirus, but a deal was coming.He insisted both sides were willing to engage each other more positively.Mr Liu added: “When it comes to a trade deal, we are open.We are ready to work with our British colleagues any time.He also praised British officials, saying they had already expressed a willingness to restart talks.The huge boost for the Prime Minister came after his first telephone call with Chinese President Xi Jinping yesterday morning.Mr Liu claimed the PM told Mr Xi that he loves China and wants to work with Beijing to lt bilateral relations to a new level.He added: They had a very good conversation.”The diplomat said the pair also talked about the relationship, how the two countries will strengthen this relationship for the next ten years.

title: lidl shop worker upskirting
story: Craig Hawick, , crouched down within the self-service checkout area to snap compromising pics of women on his mobile phone, a court heard.He pleaded guilty to committing the offences while at work at the Lidl supermarket in Aberdeen on January .The pervert was added to the sex offenders register after he admitted taking the photos.Fiscal depute Lynne McVicar said: “The CCTV showed the accused working within the self-service checkout area.“At .pm he dropped to a crouch, extended his arm under the female’s dress with his phone in his hand.“The CCTV is of such good quality that it can be seen the phone is in front camera mode. The accused ed to this female and did this a number of times.”The prosecutor said that the teen did this to another woman ten minutes later.She added: “Both were completely unaware of the accused’s actions.”The court was told Hawick’s behaviour came to light when another customer spotted him crouching down to take the snaps.When interviewed by cops two weeks later, officers said he “spoke freely” about his actions and admitted responsibility.Ms McVicar said police searched his Park Street home and seized, among other items, a laptop and a memory card.Hawick’s solicitor told the court that store management had since “followed through on disciplinary proceedings” and the teenager had lost his job.Paul Barnett argued a ban on Hawick owning any electrical equipment capable of capturing images – including mobile phones, laptops or cameras – was making “le extremely dficult”.He said: “He is a -year-old man who uses internet banking to pay his bills and he has just lost his job.“This order prevents him from having a smartphone or personal computer.”Sherf William Summers bailed the teen, and allowed him to continue using electrical gadgets.The sherf ordered background reports and told Hawick toto court at the end of March for sentencing.

title: mum transforms 415k house into 1m home
story: Lucy Kemp, , and her partner Dan Nash, , bought the “wreck” in Harborne, Birmingham, and turned it into their dream property.They became “obsessed” with the house after living opposite and their makeover took just one year to complete and cost £k.Lucy said: All of our family told us we were mad and were slightly concerned that we had bitten off more than we could chew but we could see the end vision.Of course it was only when we started work on the house that we realised the huge project that we had on our hands.“The whole house had to stripped back to bare brick, the back of the property as well as all the floor joists had to be replaced.The upstairs rooms were damp and some of the internal walls were so weak thatyou merely touched it, they would wobble!“But we ploughed on ahead anyway and have created a family home that we love – whether we’re entertaining friends or staying in.“It feels ridiculous saying we live in a million pound house now. It’s nice to know but we definitely see this as our forever home.”After knocking down the six outhouses at the back of the property, the home now boasts a  square metre kitchen extension and open plan living space.Lucy and Dan also changed the upstairs two bedrooms and kitchenette to create an entire top floor dedicated master suite for the couple.They are also constructing a studio in the garden which could be used as an office or gym.Lucy and Dan lived opposite the derelict house for seven years.When the owner of the property passed away the couple snapped it up for £, – with the sale going through in August .They moved into the property in June the following year and estimate that they spent around £, on renovating the house.Lucy said: “It looked dilapidated and we hardly ever saw the old lady who lived in the property but we always said thatthe opportunity arose, we would definitely like to buy this house.“You could see the roof was wobbly, the roof tiles were loose, the guttering was a mess and the windows were slightly rotten. The warning signs were all there but we knew we wanted to take it on and make it our forever home.”

In a ,-word blog last February about ‘genomic prediction’, he urged Britain to “push the frontiers” of the field - despite what he said would be “hysterical” arguments about “things like IQ and social mobility”.He added: “Post-Brexit Britain will be outside [the EU’s] jurisdiction and able to make faster and better decisions about regulating technology like genomics, AI and robotics.”A Labour frontbencher claimed the practice was “eugenics” with one MP from the party accusing him of trying to “play God”. No was approached for comment.It gives a useful insight into Mr Cummingsapos thinking on IQ and genetics after he wrote his blog post about a topic called ‘genomic prediction’. This is where embryos are excluded from IVF based on markers in their DNA. The practice is welcomed by some as a way of avoiding lelong illness, but has provoked an ethical debate about where to draw the line. One US-based firm, Genomic Prediction, offers parents screening to identy “genetically normal” embryos. This includes weeding out those at risk of disease. But in  the firm also developed testing to show an embryo’s risk of a low IQ. Co-founder Stephen Hsu, who Mr Cummings praised and has appeared with at No, said it would only be used to eliminate embryos with a “mental disability”. But Mr Hsu accepted people may in future select ‘designer’ intelligent babies, telling New Scientist:“I think people are going to demand that. If we don’t do it, some other company will.”On his blog, Mr Cummings quoted research saying genes have a “substantial influence” on people’s IQ, and said genomic tests - cheaper all the time - can now predict people’s heights “within a few cm”. He focused mainly on physical health, saying the “useful predictions” could avoid embryos developing diabetes, breast or prostate cancer in later le. But he added: “We will also be able to make predictions about outliers in cognitive abilities .” He warned against relying on ‘early years’ programmes like Sure Start, which he said was based on flawed evidence, to improve children’s lives. Instead he urged politicians to make policy decisions “on the basis of rational thinking and good science.”

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Tory government has finally set out its plans for a points-based immigration system to come into force on January  . The radical shake-up will block millions of aposlow-skilledapos - well, low-paid - workers from coming to the UK. After Brexit people will have to earn over £,, have a job offer and speak English to a certain level in order to get a work visa. There will be some exceptions for people who earn £, to £, in shortage areas like the NHS. But the plans have prompted an outpouring of fury from businesses and council who warn sectors like social care face disaster. In response the Home Office has told businesses they should simply end their reliance on cheap, low-skilled labour.Yet there are a whole host of unanswered questions. Home Secretary Priti Patel refused to give any overall cap or target on numbers, and wouldnapost say exactly when people will be able to bring their family.Â Thereaposs also scant information about how much applications will cost or how a sufficient level of English language will be measured. A policy statement published on Wednesday said free movement would end, laws surrounding this would be repealed and a new Immigration Bill would be introduced for a firm and fair system which would attract the high-skilled workers to create a high wage, high skill, high productivity economy. The government wants companies to train up British workers to fill vacancies but critics say the lack of investment in further education makes that dficult. Meanwhile Labour predict there will be so many carve-outs and exceptions that the system will be pointless. Ms Patel said there will still be ways for some low-skilled workers, such as Polish builders, to come to Britain. We will continue to review the labour market, she told the BBC. So how will it actually work  Hereaposs a handy guide. Skilled workers  All applicants - both EU and non-EU citizens - who want to live and work in the UK will need to gain  points to be eligible to apply for a visa. Points will be awarded for key requirementsthey can demonstrate they:Have a job offer from an approved sponsor, such as an employer cleared by the Home Office . Have a job offer that is at a required skill level . They can speak English to a certain level .Other points could be awarded for certain qualications andthere is a shortage in a particular occupation. The salary threshold for skilled migrants will be lowered from £, to £, for those coming to the UK with a job offer. Butan applicant earns less than the required minimum salary threshold - but no less than £, - they may still be able to come to the UKthey have a job offer in a specic occupation which appears on the Governmentaposs jobs shortage list, orthey have a PhD relevant to the job. This could mean lower earners such as nurses may still be able to apply for a visa, provided a shortage of staff in this area remain on the approved list. The cap on the number of people who can come through the skilled worker route has been scrapped. There are no plans to introduce regional salary thresholds or dferent arrangements for dferent parts of the UK. This would allow a small number of the most highly-skilled workers, who can gain the required level of points, to enter the UK without a job offerthey are endorsed by a relevant and competent body. This will include science, technology, engineering and mathematics professionals. Points will be awarded for factors such as academic qualications, age and relevant work experience and the route would be capped. Low-skilled workers  There will be no temporary or general visa options for low-skilled migrant workers. The paper said: UK businesses will need to adapt and adjust to the end of free movement, and we will not seek to recreate the outcomes from free movement within the points-based system. As such, it is important that employers move away from a reliance on the UKaposs immigration system as an alternative to investment in staff retention, productivity, and wider investment in technology and automation. It is estimated % of the existing EU workforce would not meet the requirements of the skilled worker route, which will help to bring overall numbers down in future, according the Home Office. It is thought there are around . million EU citizens living in the UK and most are said to be unskilled or low-skilled workers.  Last week it was reported the new system could cut the number of low-skilled migrant workers from European Union countries by up to , a year. The policy document mentioned the immigration system would reduce overall migration numbers. But the Home Office has been unable to provide more detail on how this would be achieved anda target number had been set. A pilot scheme for seasonal workers in agriculture will be quadrupled from , to , places. Youth mobility arrangements with eight countries that result in around , young people coming to the UK each year will continue. Both routes will provide employers with further ongoing flexibility in employing iniduals into lower-skilled roles, the paper said, but added: We expect employers to take other measures to address shortages. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailViewers of a BBC documentary have slammed the aposmoronsapos behind Universal Credit for hiding their fat heads in the sand - with a five-week delay for payment forcing people into a debt spiral. The last episode of three-part series Inside the Welfare State aired on Tuesday evening and focused on Bolton Jobcentre claimants Jenny, a sex attack victim, and Paula, a mum who has just £ a day to live on. Both have had to take advances on their claims to make ends meet and are living day-to-day. Twitter user Martyn G said: Just watching the BBC programme on Universal Credit and these Middle Class Morons who have been running the DWP have been hiding their fat heads in the sand with regards to the Delay in payments having a direct effect on hardship and foodbank use! Universal Credit is designed to help people who are out of work, long-term sick or on low-paid, short-term or zero-hour contracts. However critics say there are a string of problems. People must wait five weeks for their first payment. If they want to cover the gap they must borrow an aposadvanceapos against their future benefits. Meanwhile, UC ies for people in insecure work with changing hours - meaning itaposs often impossible to know exactly how much youaposll get until the end of the month. Those people include -year-old Jenny who has recently signed up for the controversial new benefit, having taken a nine-month break from work due to the stress of the assault. In the episode, she is shown to have found herself a job on a zero hour contract at a new restaurant, but her £. an hour wages and meagre benefits mean she is struggling to afford her £-a-week flat rent.  Two weeks in, she is forced to apply for a £ advance on her Universal Credit, essentially a loan which will be deducted from future payments over the next  months . Universal Credit will top up her salary, but the amount she receives in benefits reduces by p for pound she earns in salary. With it always being paid a month behind, this combination of factors means she never knows how much she will receive - and this is proving tough. Later in the episode she suffers a bad fall and cannot work for  days, and with no sick pay or savings she panics and takes out another UC advance.  Three weeks later, she is seen again working at the restaurant but in that time has only been offered one six hour sht in a week, and tells the camera she is desperate to find a proper job. And in a final cruel blow, she does not receive hardly any money from Universal Credit because it is calculated from her wages last month - and does not take into account the dficulties she has faced this month. Twitter user Amber Goodwin, chair of Hull and Hessle Labour Party, said: We need a better system and we need to scrap the ideological  week wait. We need to give people more.  Later, she tweeted: Give people more money so that they can prosper and not simply exist. Jenny was a talented hairdresser before she was raped, having been plied with alcohol by a neighbour and assaulted in her sleep, she explains, and had dreamt of becoming an air hostess - but is now crippled by anxiety and bogged down with trying to survive day to day on low pay. Twitter user Kerri Johnson said while watching the show: I quote ‘it’s just the way the system is’  That is the issue though isn’t it  that the current system is driven by a ‘process’ but no thought for the impact on the person!  Another viewer, referring to Jenny, was baffled by the short-term fix nature of Universal Credit, particularly in the case of the vulnerable but ambitious young woman. They tweeted: The  year old girl goes to the job centre, wants to work FT and gets offered a zero hours contract position with top up support through Universal Credit. While Abigail, another viewer, tweeted: Feeling saddened...seeing how just one unfortunate event can put people into situations that seem near impossible to live in, with no clear way of getting out. Thinking about just how many people live like this too. Mum-of-one Paula, , meanwhile, was left with a feeling in her throat like Iaposve been smothered and with anxiety levels through the roof after receiving her first Universal Credit payment - and with it a major shock.  Having recently moved in with her partner Aaron, the change of circumstances means Paula has to move onto Universal Credit from Job Seekers Allowance and Housing Benefit.  She had been receiving £ a fortnight from JSA and Child Credit, but Universal Credit is paid a month in arrears - and she has no savings to see her through the five-week wait for the first payment. Hoping the wait doesnapost mess us up as it has done with a lot of people sheaposs known, she tells the cameras: A lot of people have killed themselves over it, havenapost they  Needing to pay for a school unorm for daughter Lexi, work coach Lorraine offers her an advance - essentially a Universal Credit loan - of £, to get her through.  This will have to be paid back at £ a month, over  months, she is told. But a major shock is just round the corner for Paula as she gets through the five week wait only to find £. is deducted from her monthly Universal Credit payment. This leaves her with £ for the month - far less than she was expecting - which is roughly £ a day for herself, her partner Aaron, and daughter Lexi, to pay rent, food, bills - everything.  Twitter user Thomas Hemingford said: With Universal Credit and work, the system leaves people constantly chasing their tails, not knowingtheyaposll have money for bills. Itaposs no way to live, you canapost plan, and you canapost build a le like that. And then later: Universal Credit crushes people. It causes severe anxiety and mental health problems. Not just amongst adults, but children, too. It pushes people into a debt spiral. That does not help anyone. One viewer tweeted that they had worked in finance and analysis for  years before they became unable to work and went onto Universal Credit after moving towns. They said they keep meticulous budgeting spreadsheets for myself and even I came unstuck during the -week wait.

But following months of scandal, the Duke of Yorkaposs day will be much more low-key after being signicantly downgraded by his mum the Queen. Andrew has been heavily criticised for his friendship with billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein, fuelled by his car-crash Newsnight interview in which he failed to show any regret or empathy with his victims. It resulted in him being effectively apossackedapos from his royal duties while charities cut all ties with him. The Queenaposs son was due to mark the landmark occasion with a big party, similar to the one the Queen hosted for Prince Charlesaposs th in , however plans were scrapped amid the scandal. Instead, they will sit down for a family dinner at Royal Lodge - the York familyaposs Windsor home - this evening. About  people are due to attend. A group of Andrewaposs friends are also said to be planning a celebration. There were reports that several of the invited guests shunned the dinner party, forcing loyal ex-we Sarah Ferguson to desperately try to make up the numbers.According to MailOnline a number of friends have become unavailable, resulting in Fergieaposs assistant looking for replacements. The caption reads: On this day in , Prince Andrew was born at Buckingham Palace, the first child born to a reigning monarch for  years.  Happy Birthday to The Duke of York. It was the middle of the night back home, and I knew I had to tell my mum, but I wanted to give her a few more minutes of not knowing her child had cancer.”  n“I wandered around the city, which was still quite unfamiliar to me, with no idea where to go,” she continued.  n“Eventually, I called home and Mum just kept saying, ‘No.’  n“She saw me as this strong, healthy girl – it was shocking that cancer could suddenly hit me so aggressively.  n“You sometimes imagine how it may feel to be told you have cancer. nOn TV, people always seem to go numb – their hearing fades and the room around them swirls. I actually became hyper-aware. I still remember every word the doctor said to me, even now.  n“And while it’s been incredibly dficult – both for me and the people that have walked alongside me, seeing the horror of it all – I wouldn’t undo any of what I’ve been through.”  nShe added: “Before, I think I was a little lost, almost sleepwalking through my twenties. nBut now, I’ve learnt to appreciate the little things – all those beautul moments you’d otherwise take for granted – and have a purpose and a passion in raising awareness of leukaemia.”  n  nMum, , went to doctor with mysterious bruises and died a week later  nDoctors now believe that cancerous cells first started to invade Alexandra around January , when she had seen a GP in London because she was feeling rundown and had concernes she was anaemic.  nWorking in a busy law firm, when she had noticed dark circles around her eyes, she assumed it was her fast-paced lestyle taking its toll rather than anything more sinister.  nShe said: “I almost got used to having very little energy. I was working long hours and still managing to get myself to the gym three times a week, so I didn’t think it was anything overly worrying.  n“I blamed city le. I kept telling myself I’d be moving to Hong Kong soon and would feel better in a new place, with a bit of sunshine.”  nAlexandra’s doctor agreed she could be anaemic so  suggested she eat more red meat, or try an iron supplement to get her levels up.  nAssuming that would be the end of it, Alexandra turned her thoughts to her big move in early March .  nWhen her fatigue did not lt, she said: “I kept telling myself I’d just moved around the world and that feeling tired was natural – but I just wasn’t bouncing back from the jetlag.  n“As I became more comfortable with the new friends I was making out there, they remarked that I still looked pale, despite being in the sweltering heat every day.”  nAgreeing she could be anaemic, Alexandra’s doctor suggested she eat more red meat, or try noticed a dramatic bruise forming within minutes that she thought something sinister was happening.  nShe continued: “It kept developing, getting larger and larger, to the point where I was embarrassed to show it, as I could feel people staring, wondering what I’d done.  n“That seemed to almost trigger something in my body and, before long, clusters of bruises sprang up all over, with no explanation as to where they’d come from.”  nAlexandra looked up her symptoms online – and was shocked when almost all of them pointed towards leukaemia.  nSo, using healthcare benefits she had through work, in April she booked a private appointment to see a doctor, who gave her a blood test with the results back the next morning.  n“I’d just sat down at my desk when my phone started to ring,” recalled Alexandra. n  n“I don’t think the receptionist even said hello. She just asked, ‘Where are you ’ and told me to come in right away.  n“The urgency in her voice was really worrying. When I got there, I was trying to analyse the doctor’s face. I knew that something serious was going on, as he couldn’t quite look at me. Then he told me I had leukaemia.”  nAfter wandering around the city and phoning her mum, feeling shaken and disorientated, Alexandra ed to her office and broke the news to her colleagues.  n“A colleague came over to askI was okay, as I was visibly upset. I think she assumed it’d be a break-up, or homesickness – a more normal problem for a -something who had moved across the world to be facing,” she said.  n“When I told her, I watched the colour drain from her face. She sat with me and we talked it all over then, bizarrely, I actually wanted to do a bit of work while I waited for my midday appointment. My colleagues thought I was bonkers, but I needed a distraction.”  nWhen Alexandra she saw the specialist later that day she realised how gravely ill she was.  nShe recalled: “He told me I wasn’t well enough to fly back to the UK, and I needed to go straight to hospital. n“I said, aposOkay, I’ll just go home to get some thingsapos. He was good at keeping me calm, but also making me realise how much danger I was in.  n  nAdmitted to hospital, Alexandra was given a bone marrow biopsy, which confirmed her official diagnosis.  nAccording to the charity Leukaemia Care, ALL is a rapidly progressing form of the disease, with almost  cases a year diagnosed in UK adults.  nSymptoms can include fatigue, fever, frequent infections, unusual bleeding, unexplained weight loss and small purple spots on the skin known as purpura.  nThree days after her diagnosis, Alexandra began the first of four gruelling cycles of chemotherapy.  n“It all happened so quickly, I didn’t really have time to consider what I was about to put my body through. I was just focused on getting the cancerous cells eliminated,” she said.  nWhen I look back at that part of everything, it doesn’t feel like my le. The chemo made me sicker than the cancer, in a way – but I knew it was the cure, and I had to keep going.”  nTop news stories from nBy May, Alexandra had stabilised enough to fly home, where she continued the rest of her chemotherapy at Manchester’s Christie Hospital, finishing in September .  nLater that month, she began immunotherapy, where the body’s own immune system is used to fight off cancerous cells.  nShe said: “The form I had targets a specic antigen in the leukemic cells, and uses my own immune system to kill the cancer. The drug I take is slowly infused over a -day period, so I carry around a pump that delivers a very small dose every minute.”  nNow in remission, Alexandra described how her journey has made her re-evaluate le, and find value in small things she may have once taken for granted.  nShe said: “I know now I wasn’t prioritising the right things, like chasing that deal at work, or buying the latest designer handbag. Those things do have a place in le, and they are important, but they aren’t the be all and end all.  n“Now, things like sitting around the table with my family laughing, or feeling the sun on my neck in the garden – those are the moments that mean the most.  n “For a long time, I put what happened in a box, only to be opened at certain times.  n“Now I’ve gone from being obsessed that nobody would know to look at me what I’ve been through, to being proud of my scars.  n“I’ve worked through that denial to find a place of peace. I’ve found my cause in le and am so proud to be a part of the cancer community.”  nUrging people to be mindful of the bodies, she said: “You know your body better than anybody, soyou feel something has changed – however minor – then ask your doctor for a blood test,” she said.  n“The likelihood is it will be something much more minor than leukaemia, butit is serious, it’s important to catch it early. Alexandra Simpson has spoken out about her cancer battle to encourage others to be mindful of their bodies and to ask their doctors for a blood testthey are worried about any persistent symptoms. The -year-old from Llandudno, north Wales, is now in remission but, to lessen the risk of relapsing she is also having a stem cell transplant, having started a week of chemotherapy before having the procedure on February . Alexandra was  when she started suffering from fatigue and blamed her tiredness on her massive career move from London to Hong Kong.It was only when mysterious bruises popped up all over her body that Alexandra saw a doctor, reports WalesOnline. Still believing she had the world at her feet, Alexandra relived her horror when she received her blood test results the following day, saying: The doctor told me, ‘It’s not great news, todayapos. It was the middle of the night back home, and I knew I had to tell my mum, but I wanted to give her a few more minutes of not knowing her child had cancer.” “I wandered around the city, which was still quite unfamiliar to me, with no idea where to go,” she continued. “Eventually, I called home and Mum just kept saying, ‘No.’ “She saw me as this strong, healthy girl – it was shocking that cancer could suddenly hit me so aggressively. “You sometimes imagine how it may feel to be told you have cancer. On TV, people always seem to go numb – their hearing fades and the room around them swirls. I actually became hyper-aware. I still remember every word the doctor said to me, even now. “And while it’s been incredibly dficult – both for me and the people that have walked alongside me, seeing the horror of it all – I wouldn’t undo any of what I’ve been through.” She added: “Before, I think I was a little lost, almost sleepwalking through my twenties. Working in a busy law firm, when she had noticed dark circles around her eyes, she assumed it was her fast-paced lestyle taking its toll rather than anything more sinister. She said: “I almost got used to having very little energy. I was working long hours and still managing to get myself to the gym three times a week, so I didn’t think it was anything overly worrying. “I blamed city le. I kept telling myself I’d be moving to Hong Kong soon and would feel better in a new place, with a bit of sunshine.” Alexandra’s doctor agreed she could be anaemic so  suggested she eat more red meat, or try an iron supplement to get her levels up. Assuming that would be the end of it, Alexandra turned her thoughts to her big move in early March . When her fatigue did not lt, she said: “I kept telling myself I’d just moved around the world and that feeling tired was natural – but I just wasn’t bouncing back from the jetlag. “As I became more comfortable with the new friends I was making out there, they remarked that I still looked pale, despite being in the sweltering heat every day.” Agreeing she could be anaemic, Alexandra’s doctor suggested she eat more red meat, or try an iron supplement to get her levels up.  ]] So, assuming that would be the end of it, she turned her thoughts to her big move in early March . She continued: “It kept developing, getting larger and larger, to the point where I was embarrassed to show it, as I could feel people staring, wondering what I’d done. “That seemed to almost trigger something in my body and, before long, clusters of bruises sprang up all over, with no explanation as to where they’d come from.” Alexandra looked up her symptoms online – and was shocked when almost all of them pointed towards leukaemia. She sat with me and we talked it all over then, bizarrely, I actually wanted to do a bit of work while I waited for my midday appointment.
